Award.AwardTitle: From Stereotype Threat to Stereotype Threats: Testing a Multi-Threat Framework

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project builds upon recent advances in stereotype threat research by investigating a Multi-Threat Framework that distinguishes between different forms of stereotype threat. Situational aspects of academic and organizational environments, such as filling out demographic information immediately before taking a test, being the only woman in an engineering firm, or being the only racial minority in an upper division course at an elite university, can make salient negative stereotypes that elicit a cascade of distracting thoughts and concerns. Stereotype threat research reveals that these concerns ultimately create disparities in cognition, motivation, and performance in stereotype-relevant tasks and fields. This work focuses on the psychological experience of stereotype threat and helps to explain why women, racial/ethnic minorities, and other commonly stereotyped groups are under-represented in many fields.

The proposed experiments will test the differentiability of the stereotype threats, drawing from well-established cognitive tasks and traditional stereotype threat paradigms. The first set of experiments explores the different stereotype threats that emerge in different situations. The second set of experiments explores the different stereotype threats that are likely to emerge between and within negatively stereotyped groups. The third set of experiments will employ the Multi-Threat Framework to test interventions designed to reduce the different forms of stereotype threat. Ultimately, this research can enhance our knowledge of who is at risk for stereotype threat, when they are at risk, why they are at risk, and how to reduce that risk. In addition, given that the topic of stereotype threat is of interest to undergraduate and graduate students, this research will facilitate hands-on research training as well as conference participation and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When it comes to explaining achievement gaps and social disparities between majority and under-represented groups, commentators and researchers alike often focus on cultural, parental, or even biological factors. However, another factor, the psychological experience of stereotype threat—a concern about confirming a negative stereotype associated with one's group—demonstrates that situational aspects of academic and organizational environments can also create disparities in cognition, motivation, and performance in stereotype-relevant fields (Steele, Spencer, & Aronson, 2002).

A closer look at this literature reveals that “stereotype threat” often means different things to different researchers and is often employed to describe and explain distinct processes and phenomena. The present research takes a more fine-grained approach to stereotype threat, proposing a novel conceptualization of multiple, qualitatively distinct stereotype threats that are elicited by different variables, are moderated and mediated by different factors, are experienced to different degrees by different groups, and most importantly, will require different interventions to overcome. Specifically, the Multi-Threat Framework (Shapiro & Neuberg, 2007, PSPR) outlines six core stereotype threats that emerge from the intersection of two dimensions—the target (the self/one’s group) and the source (the self/others) of the stereotype threat. The proposed research aimed to differentiate between these stereotype threats, clarifying the relevant underlying mechanisms. The final goal was to examine the utility of the Multi-Threat Framework for guiding the development of effective stereotype threat-reducing interventions.

We tested these aims across 8 studies. First, across one set of studies we found that different negatively stereotyped groups experience different stereotype threats. Specifically, groups that tend to foster group identification, such as race and religion, tend to put people at risk for group-as-target stereotype threats (concerns about poorly representing the group) whereas groups that do not engender high group identification, such as mental health or weight, tend to avoid these pressures. On the other hand, given that stereotype endorsement tends to be higher for people contending with mental health or weight stigma (compared to other stigmatized identities), these individuals tend to be a greater risk for self-as-source stereotype threats (concerns about learning that one is indeed stereotypic; Shapiro, 2011, PSPB).

In another set of studies we manipulated group- and self-as-target stereotype threats in a sample of women contending with mental illness. Consistent with our previous research, we find that when gender is salient, these women tend to suffer stereotype threat driven performance decrements when experiencing either group- or self-as-target stereotype threats (concerns about poorly representing the group and concerns about personally being seen as stereotypic, respectively). However, when mental health is salient, these women only experienced self-as-target stereotype threat performance decrements. Consistent with these findings, in a sample of Black undergraduate students, we find that group- and self-as-target stereotype threats require different interventions. That is, group-as-target stereotype threat performance decrements were mitigated by role model interventions, interventions that reduce the pressure to represent the group. However, self-affirmation interventions, interventions that highlight one’s own strengths outside the stereotyped domain were only successful at protecting against self-as-target stereotype threat performance decrements (Shapiro, Williams, & Hambarchyan, 2013, JPSP). Thus, this set of studies provides evidence for the theoretical and practical importance of differentiating between stereotype threats.

In another set of studies we explore ingroup members as a possible source of stereotype threat. Previous research argues that ingroup members reduce stereotype threat because they reduce the pressure to positively represent the group (ingroup members can share this burden). However, we find ingroup members can be a source of stereotype threat for Black and Latino students when they are concerned about poorly representing the group (group-as-target stereotype threat), compared to representing their own abilities (self-as-target stereotype threat). Specifically, we find that this increases concerns about letting an ingroup member down.

This research has clear intellectual merit. To date, research has considered stereotype threat a one-dimensional construct that will ultimately require the same interventions. The present program of research suggests that this is not the case—to understand the causes of stereotype threat and to administer the strongest interventions, we will need to understand the specific forms that stereotype threat can take.

This research also has clear broader impacts. The conduct of this research was critical to the training of many undergraduate and graduate scholars, the majority of which are from under-represented groups. These students are now in graduate programs or faculty positions. This research was presented nationally and internationally and published in high impact outlets. In addition, the PI has given many talks on this research to audiences such as business practitioners, UCLA teachers (e.g., Math TAs, Physics faculty, Life Sciences faculty), many non-Psychology organizations interested in reducing disparities (e.g., the Anita Borg institute, State of California Stigma and Discrimination Advisory Committee, NIH Subcommittee on Peer Review), and at many non-Psychology conferences (e.g., Association of American Medical Colleges, STEM education panels).
